case_name: Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax v. Tea Company

facts.text: This appeal is by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Income-tax Reference Case No. 10 of 1962

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, is against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Income-tax Reference Case No. 10 of 1962, and raises the question as to whether the amount realized by the sale of grevelia trees as firewood is a revenue receipt and liable to tax under the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950

facts.text: The appeal raises the question whether the amount realized by the sale of grevelia trees as firewood is a revenue receipt liable to tax under the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950

anchor.surface_text: and raises the question as to whether the amount realized by the sale of grevelia trees as firewood is a revenue receipt and liable to tax under the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950  XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: The respondent is a company which carries on the business of manufacturing and selling tea

anchor.surface_text: The respondent is a companypany which carries on the business of manufacturing and selling tea.

facts.text: The respondent grows grevelia trees in its different tea estates for the purpose of affording shade to the tea bushes

anchor.surface_text: For the purpose of affording shade to the tea bushes, the respondent grows grevelia trees in its different tea estates.

facts.text: During the accounting year relevant to the assessment year 1957-58, the respondent received Rs. 600-12-0 by the sale of grevelia firewood

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year relevant to the assessment year 1957-58, the respondent received a sum of Rs. 600-12-0 by the sale of grevelia firewood and this amount was included by the Agricultural Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Quilon,

facts.text: The Agricultural Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Quilon included the Rs. 600-12-0 in computing the agricultural income of the respondent

anchor.surface_text: and this amount was included by the Agricultural Income-tax Officer, Special Circle, Quilon, in companyputing the agricultural income of the respondent.

facts.text: The respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax Sales Tax, Quilon, contending that the sum was a capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: The respondent appealed to the Deputy Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax Sales Tax, Quilon, companytending that the said sum was a capital receipt, but the Deputy Commissioner rejected the companytention.

facts.text: The Deputy Commissioner rejected the respondent's contention that the sum was a capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: but the Deputy Commissioner rejected the companytention.

facts.text: The respondent filed a second appeal to the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Appellate Tribunal reiterating the contention

anchor.surface_text: The companytention was reiterated by the respondent in second appeal filed by it to the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: The Appellate Tribunal held by order dated August 2, 1962 that the sum could not be considered a revenue receipt and was not liable to be included in agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal by its order dated August 2, 1962, held that the said sum companyld number be companysidered to be a revenue receipt and was number therefore liable to be included in companyputing the agricultural income of the respondent.

facts.text: On a reference made to the High Court, the Division Bench agreed with the Tribunal and answered the question in favor of the respondent

anchor.surface_text: On a reference made to the High Court, the Division Bench agreed with the Tribunal and answered the question in favor of the respondent.

facts.text: The appellant applied to this court and obtained special leave

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereupon applied to this companyrt and obtained special leave.

facts.text: Appellant's contention is that the sale proceeds of the firewood of the grevelia trees constituted agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that the sale proceeds of the firewood of the grevelia trees companystituted agricultural income.

facts.text: Respondent's contention is that the grevelia trees of the tea estates constituted capital assets

anchor.surface_text: The companytention for the respondent is that the grevelia trees of the tea estates of the respondent companystituted capital assets.

facts.text: There is no controversy that owners of tea estates plant grevelia trees not for deriving income but solely for providing shade for tea plants

anchor.surface_text: There is numbercontroversy about the fact that the owners of tea estates plant grevelia trees number for the purpose of deriving any income therefrom but solely for the purpose of providing shade for the tea plants

facts.text: Shade from grevelia trees is essential for the proper cultivation of tea

anchor.surface_text: and that such shade is essential for the proper cultivation of tea.

facts.text: The grevelia trees were cut down and sold after they had become useless by efflux of time

anchor.surface_text: The trees were cut down and sold after they had become useless by efflux of time.

facts.text: The grevelia trees in the tea estate of the respondent constituted capital assets

anchor.surface_text: The grevelia trees in the tea estate of the respondent companystituted therefore capital assets

facts.text: Proceeds derived from sale of grevelia trees as firewood do not constitute agricultural income under the Act

anchor.surface_text: and the proceeds derived therefrom by sale as firewood would number companystitute agricultural income under the Act.

facts.text: The sale proceeds of grevelia trees which had become useless did not fall within the definition of agricultural income under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether the sale proceeds of grevelia trees which had become useless, did number fall within the definition of agricultural income under the Act.

by special leave, is against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Income-tax Reference Case No. 10 of 1962, and raises the question as to whether the amount realized by the sale of grevelia trees as firewood is a revenue receipt and liable to tax under the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950 XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act.

special leave. The contention of the appellant is that the sale proceeds of the firewood of the grevelia trees constituted agricultural income. The contention for the respondent is that the grevelia trees of the tea estates of the respondent constituted capital assets.

Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950 XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act. The facts leading to the case may be briefly stated. The respondent is a company which carries on the business of manufacturing and selling tea. For the purpose of affording shade to the tea bushes, the respondent grows grevelia trees in its different tea estates.

anchor.surface_text: section 2 of the Kerala Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1950 XXII of 1950 , hereinafter called the Act, defines agricultural income as follows Agricultural income means  1  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes  2  any income derived from such land in the State by agriculture,

anchor.surface_text: Agricultural income means  1  any rent or revenue derived from land which is used for agricultural purposes  2  any income derived from such land in the State by agriculture, or the performance by a cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind to render the produce raised or received by him fit to be taken to market, or the sale by a cultivator or receiver of rent-in-kind of the produce raised or received by him, in respect of which numberprocess has been performed than a process of the nature described in sub-clause  ii .
